I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Strategy 2030 focuses on seven operational priorities necessary to achieve the Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB’s) vision of a prosperous, inclusive, resilient, and sustainable Asia and 
the  Pacific.1 Operational  Priority  6  (OP6)  concentrates  on  strengthening  governance  and 
institutional capacity, and the related operational plan commits to strengthening country systems 
and standards as a strategic priority.2 In alignment with this operational plan, this knowledge and 
support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  help  strengthen  the  fiduciary  systems3 of  selected 
developing member countries (DMCs) by (i) developing a methodology for conducting integrated 
fiduciary risk assessments (IFRAs)4 at the country, sector, and agency levels that can contribute 
to ADB’s country partnership strategies (CPSs); (ii) testing the methodology in selected DMC CPS 
processes  and  financing  DMC  and/or  donor-led  fiduciary  assessments;  and (iii)  supporting 
specific strengthening activities in response to identified weaknesses.  
2.  This TA is included in the Technical Assistance Special Fund corporate priority list for 
2020.  
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Global declarations on aid effectiveness (e.g., Paris, Accra, Busan, and Mexico) and other 
related literature make a strong case for the use of country systems by development finance 
providers.5 ADB has endorsed these international declarations and is committed to their agenda. 
The main argument for using country systems is to shift the focus of ADB, other development 
partners, and DMC governments toward strengthening countries’ own systems and institutional 
capacity (as opposed to using parallel systems), and thus improve the impact and sustainability 
of development initiatives.  
4.  Strategy 2030 recognizes that robust governance and institutional capacity foster public 
and private sector confidence, providing an environment conducive to increased economic 
investment and growth. By prioritizing DMCs’ governance and institutional capacity through OP6, 
ADB is aligning its aspirations for Asia and the Pacific with the global commitments in the 2030 
Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).6 SDG 16 acknowledges the unfinished governance 
agenda worldwide and calls on countries to build effective, accountable, and inclusive institutions 
at all levels, promote the rule of law, enhance government transparency, and reduce corruption.  
 
1 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
2 ADB. 2019. OP6—Strengthening Governance and Institutional Capacity Operational Plan 2019–2024. Manila. 
3 “Country [fiduciary] systems and procedures typically include, but are not restricted to, national arrangements and 
procedures for public financial management, accounting, auditing, procurement, results frameworks and monitoring” 
(Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development Assistance Committee. 2005. Paris Declaration. Paris). 
4 An IFRA is a holistic assessment of the existing fiduciary (i.e., financial management and procurement) systems 
within a DMC, delivered in a harmonized manner.  
5 Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness 2005; Accra Agenda for Action 2008; Global Partnership for Effective 
Development Cooperation 2011; Cusco Declaration on Procurement and Manila Consensus on Public Financial 
Management 2011; Mexico High Level Meeting Communique 2014; Addis Ababa Action Agenda 2015; Organization 
for Economic Co-operation and Development. Aid Effectiveness. www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness.  
6 United Nations General Assembly. 2015. Transforming Our World: The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. 
New York.

2 
5.  The delivery of efficient and effective services by state institutions to its citizens requires 
robust country fiduciary systems.7 Ensuring that ADB projects utilize such country systems 
effectively is one of the three strategic pillars of the OP6 operational plan, which notes the need 
to help DMCs identify issues constraining their country systems and commits ADB to accelerate 
its  support  to  strengthen  them.  Helping  to  improve  governance  standards  increases  the 
sustainability  of  ADB-financed  activities,  while  also  having  a  multiplier  effect  of  improving 
transparency and accountability in the use of public funds, including those of other development 
partners. 
6.  ADB’s commitment to strengthen country systems reinforces its earlier initiatives. In 2006, 
ADB developed the Second Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan (GACAP II), a diagnostic 
tool for carrying out governance risk assessments (GRAs) in financial management, procurement, 
and anticorruption. The GACAP II informs, through risk assessment and management plans 
(RAMPs), the governance risk section of ADB’s CPSs, sector strategies, and project designs; 
provides guidance on the use of country systems; and identifies areas for strengthening.8  
7.  To complement the GACAP II and increase focus on fiduciary risks, ADB in 2014 and 
2015 enhanced its level of fiduciary due diligence by developing country and sector/agency 
procurement  risk  assessments  (CSPRAs)  and  updating  project-level  financial  management 
assessments guidance. The CSPRA predominantly covers country and sector/agency risks 
whereas  the  financial  management  assessment  focuses  on  project-level  risks.  A  more 
comprehensive methodology to inform financial management risk and mitigating measures at the 
country and sector levels is still needed. 
8.  In 2019, ADB evaluated past CPSs and related RAMPs completed in the last 10 years, 
and identified limitations and areas for change.9 For example, while GRAs were performed for 
each of the eight CPSs approved in 2019, options for strengthening and using DMC systems for 
financial management and procurement were not effectively pursued.10 In addition, different 
approaches used for procurement and financial management RAMPs in CPSs and projects made 
it challenging to obtain an integrated view of country fiduciary systems.  
9.  Across ADB’s DMCs, completed CSPRAs have highlighted weaknesses in governments’ 
systems and processes, including existing legislation which, in some cases, does not follow best 
international practices. Past ADB GRAs have also underlined limitations in country and sector 
public financial management systems. These issues are often compounded by capacity deficits 
at the implementation level and together they undermine the performance of country systems and 
ADB’s ability to permit their use on projects. 
10.  The Procurement, Portfolio and Financial Management Department (PPFD) also noted in 
its operational reviews that DMCs’ weak institutions and governance and the inadequate capacity 
of executing and implementing agency staff affect project financial sustainability and impact 
 
7 For this purpose, “institutions” mean the organizations that implement and/or oversee the implementation of public 
projects and programs. They extend from the central government agencies responsible for budget planning, 
execution, and reporting (e.g., finance, planning, and sector ministries) to the institutions responsible for budget 
monitoring and oversight (e.g., supreme audit agencies), and include both national and subnational institutions, 
sectoral and program-level institutions, and public sector and quasi-private sector institutions, such as state-owned 
enterprises. For the purposes of this paper, “fiduciary” refers to procurement and financial management systems. 
8 ADB. 2006. Second Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan (GACAP II). Manila.  
9 ADB. Second Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan Implementation, 2006–2018: Achievements and Learnings 
Report. Manila (internal); and ADB. 2013. Implementation Review: Second Governance and Anticorruption Action 
Plan (GACAP II). Manila. 
10 In 2019, the CPSs for Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bhutan, Cambodia, Fiji, Georgia, Nepal, and Uzbekistan were approved.

3 
compliance with the submission of audited project financial statements and other ADB financial 
management  requirements. 11  Proactive  integrity  reviews 12  completed  by  the  Office  of 
Anticorruption  and  Integrity  have  reported  that  DMCs  are  challenged  by  weak  financial 
management  and  procurement  systems  and  capacity  due  to  a  lack  of  qualified  staff 
knowledgeable in financial management and procurement, non-adherence to recognized financial 
reporting standards, and substandard fiduciary systems and processes.13  
11.  Recognizing DMC capacity issues and limitations, regional departments within ADB have 
been processing TA projects with a focus on strengthening the capacity of executing and 
implementing agencies.14 These TA projects focus on the agencies’ capacity and arrangements 
to procure, account, report, and audit project funds; and would benefit from a streamlined 
approach to assessing country, sector, and agency fiduciary systems. 
12.  Given these observations and in line with the targets in OP6, ADB should further augment 
its approach to conducting assessments and helping strengthen country systems. An improved 
approach  that  combines  financial  management  and  procurement  assessments  will  enable 
diagnostic and subsequent strengthening activities to be delivered in a more integrated, efficient, 
and holistic manner. This will also enable ADB to better support DMCs in strengthening their 
fiduciary systems and institutional capacity. 
13.  The  TA  will  help  strengthen  DMCs’  fiduciary  systems  and  capacity,  increasing  the 
possibility that ADB and other development partners will be able to utilize country systems in their 
operations. Strengthened country systems will increase the probability of successful outcomes 
for  ADB-financed  projects  and  programs  and,  more  generally,  improve  relevant  DMCs’ 
performance in public procurement and financial management. The results of both the ADB IFRA 
and  complementary  country-led  fiduciary  assessments  will  inform  this  support. 15  These 
assessments will establish a baseline from which subsequent activities for strengthening country 
fiduciary systems may be agreed and developed. 
14.  This TA aims to strengthen DMCs’ capacity and knowledge in procurement and financial 
management, including by supporting (i) executing and implementing agencies responsible for 
the delivery of ADB-financed projects; (ii) procurement institutions with a mandate to develop and 
disseminate normative guidance, oversee procurement, and undertake capacity building activities; 
(iii) comptroller generals responsible for government financial accounts and public internal control 
systems; and (iv) supreme audit institutions responsible for providing assurance on the efficient

15 Examples of country-led fiduciary assessments include Methodology for Assessing Procurement Systems, Public 
Expenditure and Financial Accountability, and Supreme Audit Institutions Performance Measurement Framework. 
These generally assess fiduciary systems at the country level and are neither completed nor updated systematically 
across all DMCs. Where available, development partner led assessments will serve as the baseline from which an 
IFRA will be prepared, and the focus will be on the sector and agency levels, reflecting the specific emphasis on CPS 
activities in a DMC and identifying, in a more targeted manner, risks that could negatively impact the implementation 
of ADB projects during the CPS term. The IFRA outputs will complement the findings of country-led assessments 
and inform the dialogue between the government and development partners on strengthening activities.

4 
use of public funds. Where applicable, this TA will promote knowledge sharing and capacity 
building through local and regional professional organizations to create a strong and reliable 
accounting and audit profession in Asia and the Pacific. 
15.  Besides the IFRAs, which will follow ADB’s CPS processing schedule, other interventions 
will be demand driven at the request of the DMCs with the endorsement of ADB regional 
departments.  ADB  will  engage  with  other  development  partners  and  regional  bodies  and 
complement ongoing initiatives in both procurement and financial management. The TA will 
prioritize support to low-income countries; countries in fragile, conflict-affected situations; and 
small island developing states. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
16.   The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  governance  and  institutional  enabling 
environment  for  sustainable  growth  improved.16 The  TA  will  have  the  following  outcome: 
performance of fiduciary systems and institutions in selected DMCs strengthened.17 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
17.  The TA will have three outputs:  
Output 1. Fiduciary assessments conducted in selected developing member countries. A 
country and sector/agency financial management assessment will be developed and merged with 
the existing CSPRA to create a single IFRA covering both financial management and procurement. 
Following testing of the IFRA in two selected DMCs, its use will be mainstreamed to allow the 
completion of comprehensive fiduciary risk assessments at the country and sector/agency level 
prior to CPS preparation, ensuring that the IFRA results flow through to project design and 
implementation.18 The IFRA will be accompanied by a suite of guidance materials and embedded 
in ADB staff instructions to ensure that a consistent and comprehensive approach is undertaken. 
Output 2. Country-led fiduciary assessments and developing member country systems’ 
strengthening initiatives supported. ADB will finance country-led fiduciary assessments and 
enhance its engagement with development partners to better contribute to the development of 
country-level  fiduciary  systems.  ADB  will  also  support  the  implementation  of strengthening 
measures to address weaknesses identified during fiduciary assessments. This may include the 
engagement of technical experts to help the government develop and implement a strengthening 
action plan, or more targeted interventions, such as technical support for policy development.  
Output 3. Developing member country institutional capacity on financial management and 
procurement strengthened. In its role as a knowledge provider, ADB will work with governments 
to strengthen the capacity of the procurement and financial management function through the 
dissemination of knowledge products and delivery of workshops, seminars, and targeted training. 
 
16 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
17 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
18 In advance of the finalization of the IFRA, the TA will support CPS processing activities in DMCs through the 
identification and mitigation of fiduciary risks using existing assessment modalities.

5 
18.  The TA approach is adopted due to the broad coverage of the activities across all DMCs, 
the technical nature of the outputs and related activities proposed, and the ability to transfer 
lessons learned on suitable strengthening activities across multiple DMCs. These activities can 
be more efficiently delivered through ADB directly managing consultants. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6: $1,000,000 and TASF-other sources: $1,000,000). 
Key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ADB will administer the TA. The PPFD will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; 
organize workshops; and provide staff to act as resource persons in the workshops. 
21.  Noting the potential impact of travel restrictions on access to DMCs due to the coronavirus 
disease pandemic, the TA period has been extended by 1 additional year to 2024. The terms of 
reference for consultants additionally require the development of contingency plans to mitigate 
the risks posed by coronavirus disease restrictions on the delivery of contract outputs. The PPFD 
will work closely with ADB regional departments to adapt implementation arrangements to 
individual  country  situations,  including  an  enhanced  role  for  resident  mission  staff  in  TA 
implementation, prioritization of activities that can be more effectively delivered remotely or 
through available in-country expertise, and leveraging of activities being undertaken by other 
donor partners within the scope of this TA.

E.  Governance 
24.  This TA will support the strengthening of country systems in procurement and financial 
management, with the aim of improving governance and institutional capacity in ADB DMCs, and 
subsequently reducing governance-related risks and increasing the potential for ADB to use 
country systems in its projects. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Integrated Fiduciary Risk Assessments and Strengthening Country Systems, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1.  Fiduciary assessments conducted in selected DMCs 
1.1. Develop and test the IFRA in two DMCs, one of which is a FCAS and/or SIDS (Q4 2021). 
1.2. Finalize the IFRA with accompanying guidance and a quality assurance mechanism (Q2 2022). 
1.3. Conduct IFRAs in selected DMCs including FCASs and SIDSs (Q2 2022–Q4 2024). 
1.4. Include relevant outputs from IFRAs in the governance section of the CPS (Q2 2022–Q4 2024). 
2.  Country-led fiduciary assessments and DMC systems’ strengthening initiatives supported 
2.1. Lead and/or support, with DMCs and other donor partners, country-led fiduciary systems assessments 
(e.g., MAPS, PEFA, and SAI-PMF) (Q1 2021–Q4 2024). 
2.2. In collaboration with selected DMCs, identify and support strengthening activities to address 
weaknesses observed in IFRAs and other assessments (Q3 2021–Q4 2024). 
3.  DMC’s institutional capacity on financial management and procurement strengthened. 
3.1. Develop capacity building programs and prepare relevant training materials (Q1 2021–Q4 2024). 
3.2. Responding to identified knowledge weaknesses, and in consultation with selected DMCs, conduct 
capacity building and knowledge-sharing events (Q3 2021–Q4 2024). 
3.3. With input from operations departments, the Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department, donor partners, and DMCs, identify, draft, and finalize suitable knowledge products (Q1 
2021–Q4 2024). 
3.4. Disseminate knowledge products across ADB and the DMCs, supported by related knowledge-sharing 
events and promotional activities (Q3 2021–Q4 2024). 
TA Management Activities 
▪  Recruit consulting firm to support the preparation and validation of the IFRAs (Q4 2020). 
▪  Establish a framework agreement for individual consultants to conduct IFRAs and other fiduciary 
assessments in DMCs (Q2 2021). 
▪  Engage consultants, as required, to draft knowledge products and deliver capacity development activities 
(Q3 2021–Q4 2024). 
▪  Undertake quality assurance of draft IFRAs and other completed assessments (Q3 2021–Q4 2024). 
▪  Support DMCs in the development of action plans to address identified weaknesses (Q4 2020–Q4 2024). 
▪  Undertake monitoring and evaluation of all capacity development activities (Q1 2021–Q4 2024).
